article_1.title: ‚ÄúGoing To Be Close‚Äù For Tristan Wirfs And Zyon McCollum

Joe presumes that meant the playbook.

article_2.title: Mike Evans ‚ÄúTrending‚Äù To Play Against Giants
article_2.post: So the greatest receiver in Bucs history was back on the practice field today with his healed/healing hamstring.Head coach Todd Bowles said Mike Evans is ‚Äútrending‚Äù to play Sunday against the Giants. Joe sure hopes the vagueness from Bowles was just to throw off the folks in New Jersey.Is Evans ready or not?Surprisingly to Joe, the Bucs were not in pads today, even though that option was available to Todd Bowles.Coming off a bye week, one in which Bowles gave his players six consecutive days off (it could have been as little as four, per league rules), Joe thought the Bucs would have an intense and physical practice. It seems that wasn‚Äôt the case.Joe will now resume praying that Evans truly is healthy when/if he returns to the field.

article_3.title: Bucs Super Bowl QB Is No Fan Of The Fire Todd Bowles Rants
article_3.post: It was very obvious this week that when former Bucs Super Bowl-winning QB Brad Johnson isn‚Äôt lighting up social media with bizarre trick shots, he‚Äôs paying close attention to the current Tampa Bay team.Johnson was a guest of multimedia icon Rock Riley on WDAE radio and was asked about calls to replace head coach Todd Bowles with offensive coordinator Liam Coen.That drew a laugh from Johnson.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs probably a little too early right now (laughs) to be making those decisions,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI mean, honestly, the Buccaneers, I think they‚Äôve had the hardest schedule in the NFL.Johnson rattled off the Bucs‚Äô tough losses and big wins against the Lions, Eagles and Commandoes.Still, Johnson didn‚Äôt take a coaching change off the table. He just wants to see more.‚ÄúPlayers are going to come and go and coaches are going to come and go, but obviously you want a quarterback to be in the same system for a long period of time ‚Äî over time,‚Äù Johnson said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôll figure that out, but I wouldn‚Äôt make those decisions now. There‚Äôs been a lot of great success with Todd Bowles as the head coach. ‚Ä¶ They got a chance. Honestly, they got a chance. They‚Äôve got seven games left and they‚Äôre playing against five quarterbacks in the next weeks on teams that have struggled. ‚Ä¶ I wouldn‚Äôt give up on this team and make coaching changes right now in the middle of the season with seven games to go. We‚Äôve got time here.‚ÄùJoe hasn‚Äôt thrown in the towel on Bowles. There are no crowns handed out in November, but Joe does know Bowles needs wins to deserve a Year 4.That starts Sunday with the tanking Giants, and then continues the following week with the sad Panthers and then home in Tampa for a whimpering two-win Las Vegas team.
article_3.article_summary: Former Bucs QB optimistic about Todd Bowles' potential.

article_5.title: Was The Bucs-Giants Outcome Revealed At A News Conference?
article_5.post: So iconic Giants running back Tiki Barber, twin brother of Bucs legend Rond√© Barber, will be calling the Bucs-Giants game this Sunday for CBS.That‚Äôs got Joe‚Äôs antennae up for nuggets Tiki might drop during his WFAN New York radio show this week. Joe has no doubt that the Barber brothers will be talking plenty behind the scenes.Of course, all the chatter in New York is about the Giants (2-8) just benching franchise quarterback Daniel Jones in favor of third-stringer, fan-favorite Tommy DeVito. But it‚Äôs equally about the Giants needing to tank for draft position.Tiki Barber said Monday that he would be studying Tuesday‚Äôs news conference of Giants head coach Brian Daboll to see if the Giants are sincere about having DeVito be successful.‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the next media availability that I‚Äôm very interested in,‚Äù Barbers said before Tuesday‚Äôs news conference.‚ÄúLike I‚Äôm really interested to see what the reaction is. Because if it‚Äôs like ‚Äòeh, whatever,‚Äô I don‚Äôt know if Tommy‚Äôs going to be successful. If it‚Äôs like they love Tommy, he‚Äôs been grinding here as the scout team quarterback. We love what he brings and we‚Äôre excited for him and we‚Äôre going to rally around them,‚Äô then he has a chance. Not to be the starting quarterback in 2025 [and] beyond, but just to be successful.‚ÄùWell, Joe heard that take from Tiki Barber on Monday and listened to the Daboll news conference yesterday. There was no excitement from the head coach raving about how DeVito has been killing it on the scout team, or barking that DeVito is a winner that will energize the team.Assuming Tiki has the pulse of the team, Joe‚Äôs conclusion was the Giants are not doing their best to win games. And that jibes with stud Giants nose tackle Dexter Lawrence going public with his dislike of the QB change.The Bucs simply cannot lose Sunday‚Äôs game.
article_5.article_summary: Barber brothers speculate on Giants benching QB for draft position.

article_6.title: The Bucs, Takeaways And Winning Football Games
article_6.post: Joe was very, very surprised no one with the Bucs had whined about this stat this year.Lousy Lovie Smith would have been bellyaching about this for weeks.We all know how defensive coaches just love takeaways. The way some of these defensive guys go on and on about takeaways, Joe swears they believe they‚Äôre more important than points.So Joe looked up how the Bucs are doing on takeaways. Bet you‚Äôll be surprised.Even with Baker Mayfield doing a solid job taking care of the football, the Bucs have just as many takeaways as they have offensive turnovers.¬†The defense has taken the ball away from opponents 12 times through 10 games. The offense has coughed the ball up 12 times.So the takeaway differential for the Bucs is dead-even, a big ol‚Äô zero.How does that rank? That puts the Bucs at No. 10 in the NFL. Who has the third-best takeaway differential? Da Bears, who very likely will can their coach in a few weeks.(Joe has friends in Chicago and touched base with a few about dead man walking Matt Eberflus. Chicago is on fire wanting his head on a platter after the latest debacle Sunday against the Packers.)Who has the fifth-worst in takeaway differential? It‚Äôs the 9-1 defending Super Bowl champion Chiefs.As Joe has preached for years, football is not about turnovers. It‚Äôs about playing fundamentally sound ‚Äî blocking, tackling and most importantly, which cannot be stressed enough, scoring touchdowns.

article_7.title: What‚Äôs Gone Wrong For Liam Coen?
article_7.post: If you are going to find something wrong with the Bucs‚Äô hire of offensive coordinator Liam Coen and the job he has done, you may have to set aside some time to discover a fault.Coen has done an outstanding job. Quarterback Baker Mayfield has improved upon a career year in 2023. The revamped offensive line is solid if not strong and seemingly improving by the week. The Bucs rank No. 3 in explosive plays.What‚Äôs there to quibble about?In an ESPN feature focused on the performance of offensive coordinators this year, reporter Jenna Laine had to do some stretching to find a Coen negative. And it really has nothing to do with Coen at all.Injuries.‚Ä¶ ‚Ä¶ The Bucs lost 50% of their scoring offense when wide receivers Mike Evans and Chris Godwin went down because of injuries, with Godwin out for the season. Mayfield is still performing at a high level but not having the threat of a downfield passing attack has hurt their chances.Yet even after Evans and Godwin went down, for the first two games after their injuries, Coen still got production. It only seemed in the last game, the loss to the 49ers, the loss of Evans and Godwin finally caught up with Coen.Joe can think of two potential negatives for Coen, and one is nitpicking.First, what has happened to Jalen McMillan and Trey Palmer? McMillan is nowhere close to the same receiver who was balling out in practice and training camp. Palmer? His numbers are way down.The second potential drawback for Coen is the final drive in the loss to the 49ers where the Bucs had to kick a field goal to tie the game (which the defense naturally shat the bed and couldn‚Äôt hold), Coen didn‚Äôt have arguably his best available offensive player on the field, Bucky Irving.It‚Äôs players, not plays. So Joe gets why the Bucs wanted Rachaad White on the field. He‚Äôs a better blocker and receiver. But he stinks running between the tackles, which is exactly what Coen called for ‚Äî with all-too-predictable results.Other than those items, Coen has done such a solid job with the offense, ‚Äúthis Joe‚Äù believes Coen will be a head coach somewhere in 2025.
article_7.article_summary: Coen excels as Bucs' offensive coordinator despite minor setbacks.

article_8.title: Bucs Defense Isn‚Äôt A Total Sieve ‚Äî But Close
article_8.post: Disturbing numbers for a defense coached up by a defensive-minded head coach.Joe remembers during the first season of Super Bowl-winning Bucco Bruce Arians‚Äô days with the Bucs, his son, Jake Arians, remarked on Twitter about what he perceived as the sky-is-falling mentality of Bucs fans.He couldn‚Äôt believe how Bucs fans curled into a fetal position and expected disaster rather than getting behind their team.Well, the younger Mr. Arians never had to go through The Lost Decade.The two hallmarks of the Lost Decade were no edge rush and defenses that got boatraced. Sound familiar?Well, Joe read¬† stats yesterday from data scientist (highfalutin title for ‚Äústatgeek‚Äù) Sam Hoppen, currently of FantasyPros and soon to be for BSPN Bet. He listed the explosive play rate for NFL defenses.(There are various definitions of explosive plays, depending on who is doing the numbercrunching. Hoppen defines explosive plays as pass or run plays of 15 yards or more.)When it comes to the Bucs, it‚Äôs gross. It seems 11 percent of opposing offenses‚Äô plays against the Bucs defense go for 15 yards or more. That puts the Bucs‚Äô defense at No. 25 for explosive play rate.The worst is the Browns who allow 12.5 percent of opponents‚Äô plays to go for at least 15 yards.With the Bucs, it really doesn‚Äôt matter if it is the run or the pass. Some 2.5 percent of runs against the Bucs defense go for 15 yards or more. That‚Äôs No. 23 in the league ‚Äî depressing considering how much Bucs head coach Todd Bowles stresses stopping the run.Pass defense? Hoppen has the Bucs ranked No. 24 with 8.7 percent of pass plays going for at least 15 yards.This may not be as bad as The Smiths (Lovie and Mike). But that‚Äôs a helluva consolation prize for a team on the brink of being out of the playoff chase.
article_8.article_summary: Bucs defense struggles with explosive plays

article_9.title: Computer Projections: Bucs‚Äô Playoff Chances A Coin Flip
article_9.post: Well, this is something very interesting to Joe.It appears whoever is programming a piece of software owned by the outfit Pro Football Network either hates the Dixie Chicks or has a very high opinion of the Bucs‚Äô defense.Why does Joe type that? Because Pro Football Network ran over 10,000 simulations of how the remainder of the schedule shakes out in order to determine each team‚Äôs playoff chances.And the software likes the Bucs‚Äô chances of playing meaningful games in January more than most playoff guesstimates.¬†In fact, Pro Football Network has the Bucs basically as a coin flip to make the playoffs, some 47.4 percent ‚Äî better than the Dixie Chicks‚Äô at 45.5 percent!Is that because whoever programmed this software believes the Dixie Chicks will choke like dogs? Does it mean the programmer is related to Todd Bowles?‚ÄúThis Joe‚Äù has to see with his own eyes the Bucs defense play much better before chugging the Kool-Aid. Hopeful, yes, but at the end of the day Joe lives in reality. And the Bucs‚Äô defensive numbers are downright awful.In half the Bucs losses, opponents scored on the final drive of the game. That is three losses squarely on the defense.Of course, ‚Äúthis Joe‚Äù is more than a wee bit concerned with Bowles‚Äô horrid history of losses coming off a bye week.
article_9.article_summary: Bucs' playoff chances analyzed through simulations by Pro Football Network software.
